resources.string:
© 2004-2006 Nokia Corp.
© 2008-2012 Dirk Trossen; 
© 2013-2014 TecVis LP 

Contact: dot@tecvis.co.uk 

Follow Us on Twitter at @tecvis 

Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/tecvisuk 

Manual: http://tecvis.co.uk/software-2/airs/ 

AIRS source code is licensed under LGPL 2.0 license and hosted on Github. For more information on license terms, review license.txt! 

Special acknowledgment goes to Dana Pavel. Using AIRS for her research work (http://dalore.me.uk/Dana/research-areas) has provided many opportunities to introduce new features (such as event and mood button) as well as improve AIRS in terms of stability and features! 

NOTE that the authors assume no responsibility for any potential misuse of this software for spying purposes. The operation is exposed through notification bar icons in order to make users aware of ongoing recordings!
Set general application settings such as server IP, watchdog information and others.

'Server' defines the address of the AIRS application server (must be public), followed by the port.

 'Local Display' toggles the output of sensor values in local sensing

 'Local Storage' switches the local storage on/off in local sensing. 

 'Sensor History' determines the number of sensor values being shown in the AIRS visualisations.

 'Wakeup' only senses in local mode when there is any other (user) activity, i.e., it does not hold a wake-lock.

 'Reminder Interval' defines the vibration and LED notification interval for the local sensing watchdog (0 switches the vibrate off)

 'Debug' switches the debug output on/off.

Shows a path of recent GPS recording. You can click on a marker for more information. You can center the map either on your current location or the last stored one (using the buttons on the top right). You can also switch between map or satellite view with the appropriate options menu item.

Shows the AIRS online manual.\nYou will need Internet access for the page to show. You can click on links to various manual chapters like on any other webpage. Use the BACK key to navigate back to higher levels or exit the manual at the main level.

Start recording here, selecting the mode of recording you would like.

You can also load and delete templates that you stored as well as create shortcuts to a selected template on your launcher screen. Clicking on a template will automatically load the template.

Instead of defining your own templates, you can also download examples from the TecVis server.

Shows the sensors available in local sensing mode.\nChoose the sensors you would like to record. Through the menu, you can select and unselect all sensors (for a clean sheet) as well as look at the sensor repository, giving you information on type, value ranges etc of the sensors that were discovered.

Shows the current values of the sensors being read in local mode.\nFrom here, you can either Exit the program (and stop the service) or simply stop the display with the BACK key!\nYou can also PAUSE or RESUME the measurement threads (this does not stop the service but halts the recordings only).
Shows the number of values and the bytes being sent in remote mode.\nFrom here, you can either Exit the program (and stop the service) or simply stop the display with the BACK key!

Select the mood you are currently in. Your selection is recorded with a timestamp in the MO sensor.\nExit the selector without selection by using the BACK key!\nYou can define your own mood entry in the text field at the bottom.

Select the type of event you are currently in. Your selection is recorded with a timestamp in the EB sensor.
Exit the selector without selection by using the BACK key!
You can define your own event entry in the text field at the bottom. You can delete any entry by long clicking on it and confirming the deletion.

AIRS stores your last defined events persistently.
Shows a historical timeline of the sensor you just clicked on. You can change the number of historical values in the General Settings\nExit the timeline by using the BACK key!
Choose any of the three DB actions, namely Backup, Restore or Index. You can only index the DB once and cannot undo the indexing after it is done.
Allows for sharing the data since the last synchronisation as a text file.\n\nYou can also manually set the last sync date, in case you need to re-sync periods.
This list shows you the most visited WiFi APs over a given period. Only APs that you have connected to will be shown here!
Select the sensors you want to record as well as configure various available settings for the sensors! You can also configure General Settings for AIRS.

For local recording:
 - select 'Lifelogging' for lifelogging settings
 - press 'Shortcut' to place a shortcut on your launcher homescreen
 - place AIRS event and mood widgets on your homescreen for annotations
 - adjust settings as you like, e.g., adding WiFi hotspots to your adaptive GPS list!
 - start 'AIRS local' recording from your launcher screen with the created shortcut!
 - for more complex visualisations of your recordings, download our Storica app at http://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.storica
 - for more information on recording, see http://tecvis.co.uk/software/storica/tips-for-recording

 For remote recording, download the AIRS application server (see on our website) and read the AIRS online manual through the options menu
Connect to Google Account for GDrive Backup
Wait for connecting to your Google Account!
Cannot find Google Account information on this device!
You need to grant access for the upload function to work!
Select the folder in GDrive root directory to upload to - will be created if it does not exist. This setting is specific for each recording template!
Cannot backup database while AIRS is running!
Cannot restore database while AIRS is running!
Cannot create backup file (possible access error or external media does not exist)!

Indexing your database greatly improves the performance in retrieving values for visualisation but will increase the size of your database by about 60%! You only need to index once.\n\nDo you want to continue?
Cannot index DB file (Possibly indexed already or possible access error or external media does not exist)!
Cannot restore DB file (Possible access error or external media does not exist)!
You need to enable at least one sensor before starting the measurements!
Exit will stop your recording and close the background service!\nAre you sure you want to exit?
Nothing to share, it seems! Have you set the camera path to the right one (the path need to the SAME as shown for pictures in the Gallery applications!).
AIRS has been running.\nDo you want to interrupt the current recording and start over? You will need to start AIRS again.
AIRS has been running.\nDo you want to interrupt the current recording and start over? You will need to start the shortcut again.
Started AIRS local service!\nYou can see its current view by clicking on the notification bar update.
You need at least one template being saved AND selected from the list before you can create a shortcut!
You need at least one template being saved AND selected from the list before you can delete a template!
Created AIRS shortcut on launcher homescreen!
Created AIRS template and shortcut on launcher homescreen!
Loading the template will override the current settings!\nAre you sure?
Filename to Save Settings as Template
Are you sure you want to start remote sensing?\n\nAIRS will attempt to connect to the remote application server, blocking the ability to exit the AIRS service until the connection request times out.
Sensing not running!\nThe service might have crashed!
You can set the last sync date here (starting at 00:00 in the morning). It will overwrite your current sync timestamp!
Do you want to interrupt synchronisation?
There are no values to synchronise!
You have selected regular uploads in your general settings and can therefore not manually synchronise!
Do you want to delete this annotation from the list?
Cannot find the shortcut preference file! Please recreate the shortcut.
Select which sensors you would like to record

Senses the surrounding sound environment.

The sensor values are frequency or average amplitude of a sound sample.
The sampling rate and the polling interval for the sampling can be set in order to optimize the reading and processing requirements.

Senses surrounding Bluetooth devices.

The sensor values are of the format MAC::name for each discovered device.
All service devices are attempted to be discovered so that all discoverable BT devices should be sensed.
The user can be asked to switch on BT if it is switched off before starting the sensing.
Retrieves calendar entries from your available calendars!\nYou can select the calendars that AIRS should monitor. The calendars are polled frequently for upcoming events.
Various phone-based information like orientation, proximity, RAM, battery etc

Senses various phone-based sensors and system information.\n\nThe orientation is only supported for models with internal compass. Other information includes proximity as well as system information such as battery, RAM and tasks.
Obtains various environmental information, such as light, barometer and weather conditions at current location
Obtains environmental information such as light, barometer, and various weather conditions (temperature, humidity, …) at the current location through an online weather API.
A button widget to mark meaningful events

Allows for marking meaningful events through a homescreen (button) widget.

The user can input their own meaningful description for the event to be marked.
AIRS stores the most recently defined descriptions with the maximum number to be stored configurable.
HxM BT Heart rate monitor from Zephyr with pulse and instant speed support
Senses heart rate values from Zephyr\n\nYou can enable the heart monitor sensing here as well as select the device to connect to.
Various location sources like GPS, Wifi and cell

Senses location-related information.

The sensor values are location values, utilizing cell identification info, Wifi beacon information as well as GPS.
cellID is a simple integer, GPS will give long/lat, and WLAN the MAC address, SSID as well as signal strength of nearby access points. 

The settings allow for selecting the poll intervals for Wifi and GPS. Also, you can force to refresh AGPS information frequently, forcing a download of GPS ephemeral information from the network (only supported on some phones).
Watch various media folder such as camera, music, …

Watches various media-related folders.

Camera, music and other folders can be watched with respect to creating new files, such as when taking a picture.
For setting the right camera folders, go into the Gallery application, display any recent picture you have taken, display the 'Details' and look for the 'Path' entry. Select the entire path (before the actual filename) as the path for the camera folder!
Records notifications from IM programs (currently Skype and Google Talk) and Spotify

Captures notifications from certain IM programs as well as from Spotify.

Currently, Skype and Google Talk are supported. Skype only provides the name of the person you are chatting with, while Google Talk provides name and message.
Spotify information is recorded as track and artist (album information is not provided by Spotify).
The sensor is implemented as a so-called Accessibility service and you need to enable its usage in the system settings (which the settings entry will lead you to).
If you want to re-sync, set sync date from the Options menu!
Address of your AIRS application server
Port of your AIRS application server
Display sensor values you subscribed to
Do not display sensor values, only number of values sensed
Store sensor values in internal SQLlite database
Set the frequency of uploading recordings to GDrive (or not at all)
Send system intents to allow for, e.g., external rule engine such as AIRS Ruler
Wakeup phone during sensing only when there is other user activity
Keep wake lock to prevent sleeping
Kill AIRS based on battery level to conserve some spare battery (0 = disable)
Interval for reminder that AIRS is running (0 = disable)
Use notification LED as a reminder
Do not use notification LED as a reminder
Sampling rate for audio capture in Hertz
Interval to wait after each audio capture in seconds
Adjustment in dB for Sounds Pressure Level
Programmatically enable BT, if switched off
Requests user permission when enabling BT
Switch on BT without explicit user permission
Poll interval for BT scanning in seconds
Choose the calendars that you want to have watched
Poll interval for orientation sensor in seconds
Poll interval for proximity sensor in seconds
Poll interval for system information like RAM, tasks, etc
Poll interval for light and barometer sensor in seconds
Poll interval for weather update in minutes
Update weather when moved more than a certain distance (or always)
Update accuracy for GPS location in meters
Maximum number of event descriptions to be stored
Sort annotation texts in list that shows after selecting the annotation widget
Do not sort annotation texts in list that shows after selecting the annotation widget
Use heart monitor, attempting to connect at start of discovery
Use Q sensor, attempting to connect at start of discovery
Choose one of the possible devices to connect to. You first need to pair with the device in the BT system settings! Make sure the device is switched on when starting AIRS.
Choose one of the possible BT Smart devices to connect to. Make sure the device is switched on when starting AIRS.
Choose one of the possible device types to use for recording.
Bt Smart not supported on this device!
Make sure BT is switched on!
Time window for averaging the pulse measurements, smoothening the values and reducing the numbers of recordings.
Enable GPS to show up in sensor list
Use Wifi and network information for location
Use Wifi data to temporarily switch off GPS for better battery life. This might lead to delays in locating you once leaving WiFi zones since GPS will need to be re-started.
Do not use WiFi information to temporarily switch off GPS for better battery life
Choose the WiFi access points in which proximity GPS recording will be switched off. You will need to subscribe to the WI sensor for this setting to have an effect.
Shows you the most visited WiFis in a given period so that you can optimise your adaptive GPS.
Long click on any entry in the list to see how often you visited this WiFi access point.
Connect to at least one WiFi!
Cannot find recent recordings for WiFi - record the WI sensor for some time!
Poll interval for GPS location in seconds
Interval to force AGPS refresh in hours (0 = disable)
Programmatically enable WiFi, if switched off
Do not enable WiFi, if switched off
Let WiFi sleep according to system settings
Poll interval for WiFi scanning in seconds
Jumps to System settings to enable the accessibility service required for capturing IM and Spotify notifications.
Jumps to System settings to enable the notification listener service in the "Notification access" menu of this system setting!

Accessibility service for AIRS local sensing, providing access to the Google Talk and Skype notifications through the NO sensor. It also supports Spotify song changes through the MP/MA/MT sensors.\n\nIMPORTANT: For Android 5.0 upwards, please choose the notitication listener instead (in your Sound and Notification settings) and disable the accessibility listener here!
Select a picture from the camera directory to determine the correct camera path!
Could not retrieve the path! Did you select a picture that resides on the device?
Cannot add image(s) from outside camera directory to AIRS database!
Provides the estimated audio frequency, determining the sound pitch. Measured in Hz.
Provides the estimated noise level, measured in dB.
Provides information about the BT devices around, such as MACs and BT names.
Provides the number of BT devices around.
Provides the BT device(s) the phone is connected to.
Provides blood pressure values that are annotated by the user through the blood pressure phone widget.
Provides the current calendar event(s) from the selected calendar(s).
Provides the roaming status (0 if not roaming, 1 if roaming).
Provides the status of GPRS (0 if off, 1 is on).
Provides the strength of the cellular signal in dBm with -113dBm meaning \'no signal\'.
Provides the strength of the cellular signal in number of bars.
Provides the current cell identifier as given by the mobile operator.
Provides the current location area code as given by the mobile operator.
Provides the current mobile country code as given by the mobile operator.
Provides event descriptions annotated by the user through the Event Widget.
Provides text shared to AIRS from any application that allows it.
Provides a combined Long:Lat:Alt string for GPS.
Provides the heading based on GPS with 0 degrees being North.
Provides speed in meters-per-second based on GPS.
Provides heart rate/pulse through the Zephyr HxM monitor.
Provides speed in meter-per-second through the Zephyr HxM monitor.
Provides the battery level of the Zephyr HxM monitor.
Provides filenames of media newly created within the pre-defined folder, such as for detecting snapshots taken.
Provides mood as selected or created by the user through the Mood Widget.
Provides information about the music playing (artist:album:track).
Provides artist for the current music track.
Provides album name for the current music track.
Provides name for the current music track.
Provides information on notifications from Skype and Google Hangout.
Provides the phone\'s azimuth - the angle towards the magnetic pole.
Provides the phone\'s rotation angle on the short axis relative to when laying flat and upward facing.
Provides the phone\'s rotation angle on the long axis relative to when laying flat and upward facing.
Provides proximity of any object towards the phone\'s front (usually upper side of) screen.
Provides the light intensity as measured by the phone\'s sensor.
Provides the atmospheric pressure as measured by the phone\'s sensor (if available).
Provides the step count for the recording day.
Provides the ambient temperature measured by phone\'s sensor (if available).
Provides the ambient relative humidity measured by phone\'s sensor (if available).
Provides a random value, mainly used for testing purpose.
Provides the phone battery charging status (0-if not charging; 1-if charging).
Records if anything is plugged in into the headset plug.
Provides information about an incoming call: phone number and contact name (if in phonebook).
Provides information about an outgoing call: phone number and contact name (if in phonebook).
Provides information about a received sms: phone number, contact name (if in phonebook) and message.
Provides information about a sent sms: phone number, contact name (if in phonebook) and message.
Provides currently running applications on the phone.
Provides currently running applications on the phone requiring user interactions.
Provides the current AIRS recording template.
Provides the current timezone offset in relation to UTC.
Provides the Celsius temperature as obtained from external web server.
Provides the Fahrenheit temperature as obtained from external web server.
Provides the humidity as obtained from external web server.
Provides a summarized weather info as obtained from external web server.
Provides the wind speed as obtained from external web server.
Provides a combined weather info as obtained from external web server.
Provides combined info about available WiFis.
Provides MAC addressed of available WiFis.
Provides signal strength info of available WiFis.
Provides status information (1 if phone is connected to a WiFi).

In addition to the short-term visualisations in AIRS, you can process and visualise your AIRS data with engaging multimedia graphics, using our Storica app. Click on the image below to go to the Playstore!

We added support for BLE-based heart rate monitors like Polar H7, Zephyr HxM Smart (thanks to C. Herndler for supporting this work!). We also changed backup and restore to deal with VERY large databases as well as changed the TR sensor to foreground applications for Lollipop conformity.\n We also introduced notification listener for Lollipop devices to be used instead of the accessibility service and improved the stability of the audio handler.
